text: (upbeat music)
Thank you very much
to the Talented Twelve organizing team
for inviting me to be a part of the 2021 class.
I'm excited to be a part of this class.
I'm very honored as well.
I didn't expect air pollution
to make a debut among this group,
but I'm happy to represent our field.
I will say that this title slide
is a representative of my state at the moment.
The background is Riverside, UC Riverside,
and I just moved institutions this summer,
so I'm asking for your grace at this time,
and patience with me
as I'm moving through quite the transition.
First and foremost,
I want to acknowledge
the people in my work, in my group.
Without them, the last three years
would not be possible,
Abi, Ivette, Khanh, Jennifer, Yi, Alex, and Andrea.
I would also like
to highlight the fact that my group,
we prioritize inclusion, diversity, and equity,
and we are a great team.
And that builds on the principles of workmanship
and being a good team player.
And I'll take this time also
to thank my graduate mentor,
Professor Armistead, or Ted, Russell,
at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
Without his initial support in my career
I wouldn't be here today.
I'd also like to thank my post-doctoral advisor,
Professor Heather Holmes,
now at the University of Utah.
At the time I worked with her
she was at the University of Nevada, Reno.
She has also been a force in my career
and I attribute much of my early success to them.
So thank you to my group
and thank you to my group members.
We are the Air Quality Modeling and Exposure Lab.
So I'm also front-loading acknowledgements as well,
because this work doesn't happen in a vacuum.
I have quite a few collaborators,
both in the academy
and also in the community organizing space,
and in the Community College space.
In particular,
the People's Collective for Environmental Justice,
my friends and colleagues, Chela, Jean,
Andrea, Anthony, and so many more,
My colleague Heather Smith
at the Riverside City College campus,
and also to the Community College students
that helped launch the work that has,
I think, gotten the attention of C&EN magazine.
So I just wanna thank all of those people,
and I wanna thank the sponsors for supporting my work.
I know most people have quite a bit of bio,
I'm sorry, I won't be able to present that today.
But I hope to give you a rich understanding
of the motivations for the work
that we're doing in the AQMEL group.
And so this is just an overview of the thrusts
that are currently being undertaken in AQMEL.
And so Thrust number one, I'm very excited about.
It's work at the intersection of human interactions
in air quality exposure disparities.
This is a very hot topic at the moment.
So this thrust of research
allows me to interface with sociologists,
experts in the humanities,
as well as social justice.
So I'm really excited
about the work we're able to do along Thrust one.
And Thrust two, three, and four are what you would expect
from an air quality modeler,
which is my background,
where we are looking at research at the intersection
of air quality and meteorological studies,
as well as transportation, sustainability, and mobility.
And more recently we have been embarking on work
related to computational methods.
So, I am a little bit of the odd man out.
I will talk about the principles behind the work that I do.
So I like to start off with a definition
of air pollution engineering, as I see it.
Well, in high school I was taught
this definition by Dr. Douglas Edwards,
who was a proponent for introducing young black students
to engineering very early on.
And I wanna thank Dr. Edwards at this moment,
who was my engineering instructor
at Westlake High School in Atlanta, Georgia.
So he taught me that engineering
is the application of math or science
to design or improve useful things.
And so, I applied math and science concepts
to help improve air quality.
So I consider it to be air quality engineering.
This little video here
is just showing the evolution of air pollution
over the Southeastern United States.
And embedded within this model
are the physical and chemical principles
that my colleagues in the cohort are talking about today.
So this is just the expansion of those principles
to understand air pollution
and its evolution over space and time.
And more recently, and more,
a little bit more excitingly,
I've been able to leverage the Internet of Things
and wearable air pollution technology,
in my opinion, to solve grand challenges
related to air quality to this day.
And I'll talk about some of those grand challenges here
in just a second.
So, upon arriving at UC Riverside,
which is in Southern California,
it is in the desert,
I came to learn about
several air pollution exposure disparity issues.
It was very sad to see.
It was my first time really seeing such,
such tough and harrowing experiences
of the people that live in this area.
And so, what you're seeing,
on the bottom left,
is a map of the communities that have been designated
as being disproportionately exposed.
And they are formerly known as AB 617 Communities.
The San Bernardino/Muscoy Community
is the community that I am engaged with most,
because it's close to UC Riverside,
I've developed close relationships
with those community organizers,
and I'm also on the Technical Advisory group.
So what you see on the right
are the identification of community concerns.
And so, what this tells us,
that community has a rich knowledge
of what's going on in their neighborhoods,
in regards to air pollution, water pollution.
And this is a program, this AB 617 Program,
facilitated very symbiotic work
to reduce their air pollution exposure disparities.
And so I'm just gonna move forward here.
This AB 617 Program inspired me
to look at how mobility may impact
air pollution exposure disparities.
And so, a lot of people are familiar with this study.
If you're not, we work together with community
to monitor their personal air pollution exposure
by using IoT-enabled wearable sensors.
And we collected over 900,000 data points
from a small subset of people.
This was a pilot study.
And through the power of GIS technology,
we were able to cluster these space-time transects
and classify the microenvironments
to be able to understand
how much time people were spending where,
and what their exposures were.
And not surprising,
we found that exposures
were quite diverse
across a number of different microenvironments.
And, what we found is that
the home microenvironment was the most,
was more exposed, created more adverse exposures
for the San Bernardino participants
compared to our higher income participants.
And so, I'm telling you guys about this pilot study
because it's actually launching
another effort to harness the power
of Internet of Things and wearable technology,
to be able to characterize these exposures
at larger scales,
and to be able to inform policy interventions
that may reduce the exposures
in places that we really haven't been paying attention to.
And so, one of these expanded studies
is our 2021 Community Air Grant
that is being
carried out at UC Riverside
under the leadership of Miss Ivette Torres,
who is a powerhouse in the Inland Empire Community.
She is leading this grant to,
we want to empower our community residents
with their own data.
They will have data sovereignty over their daily exposures
to understand how they are moving throughout their community
and where their hotspots are.
But mind you, this comes at the heels
of a large base of community knowledge
about the BNSF railyard,
that is overpowering this community at
the current moment.
And just for a little taste of what we're doing,
some of the more,
the future plans that we have at Berkeley,
we're gonna be looking at
also how to harness personalized data,
to understand where the communication breakdowns occur
when it comes to wildfire exposure risks.
So the hypothesis that we put forth
is that if people have access
to their own personalized data,
they may be more likely to make substantial changes
to reduce their own exposure risks.
And people may say,
well, why don't we have policy to protect people?
But the work that I do is meant
to put the power in the hands of individuals,
in the event that policy can not catch up
as fast as it needs to.
Last but not least,
we are also making strides along the computational front,
where we want to harness
the power of graphical processing units,
which is advanced computational hardware,
to potentially enhance our traditional
air quality modeling computational efficiency.
And with that, I want to thank once again my group.
That is our 2021 photo. We are hybrid.
We are across two campuses.
Actually we're in three places because Abi's in Georgia.
Please feel free to interact with my website at the QR code,
as well as my podcast
where you can hear a little bit about the under,
under the hood of academia,
especially from our scholars that are people of color.
Thank you very much Talented Twelve
and I look forward to your questions.
Thank you so much Sunni for telling us about this work.
I wondered, obviously I think all of us
in the last year and a half
have thought a lot about our exposures,
in terms of infectious disease.
You know, do you think that the awareness
is greater around just personal protection?
I mean, you talked a lot about the idea
of putting the power in people's hands.
You know, maybe you could give me your vision
of what you think the world could look like
if you have that data?
To be honest, that vision looks a lot like Google Maps.
So shout out to the scientists and engineers
behind that effort.
You should be able to pick up your cell phone
and understand what your exposure variability will be
from point A to point B.
This way you can advocate for yourself.
If you're being put into a situation
that's gonna increase your exposures adversely,
I think everyone should have access to that,
especially people that,
and communities that are disproportionately exposed.
And I'll just ask briefly one other question,
'cause you'd mentioned the idea that where you live
seems to be the biggest risk factor in terms of exposure.
Is that because of the environment outside of your household
or is it both things?
Maybe you could give us a little more information
about that part,
and how people will then be able to make decisions
when they have that information.
Wow, Lisa.
If we had an hour, I could go into it a little bit more,
but where you live is a function of socioeconomics,
historical policies regarding redlining,
social mobility, which informs air pollution exposure.
And there's a subset of people in my field
that are realizing this,
and understanding how important it is
to understand the structural and political influences
on where people are able to thrive.
So,
I just say,
us as air pollution researchers,
especially exposure people,
we need to understand that these systems
have a pretty big impact on whether or not
people breathe clean air or habitually dirty air.
Well I, we're so happy to have
learned a little bit about your work today.
Thank you so much Sunni.
(upbeat music plays out)
